instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message: Hi all, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> on the bench that came in with quite a bit of liquid damage. [URL='https://imgur.com/a/6w67nZr']Took these photos[/URL] before putting the board through an ultrasonic cleaner with sweepable frequency as per Louis's videos and dried it overnight. It's now pulling 7mA from the power supply. So far I've followed power from the charger and found that power gets all the way to <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present with 3.42v just past this chip. I checked 3 more spots of <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> across the board and I got 3.42v at each spot. Seeing as there isn't a magsafe light and there is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> I'm a little confused of what I should check next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
Did you try known good DCIN board?
Check continuity between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and central pin of Magsafe connector.

Post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message: Did try known working board. I do have continuity between center pin and pin 5 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.28v and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is non-existent.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> explains the symptom.

Inspect <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area and post its voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
There were a couple rusted probe points and some corrosion, used alcohol + toothbrush and worked a lot of it away and then got the following from <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>:
1) 3.4v
3) 3.4v
4) 0v
5) 0v
6) 3v
7) 3.3v
8) 0.2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at pins 5 & 8.
Probably need to change <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
Change <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR>.
If still the same, change <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message: Replaced <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR>, no change. Just changed <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> from donor board, all voltages are the same and still no green light. I tried plugging in the board after removing the old <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> but before putting the new one on and I did get green light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, no green light
threads.message:
Pin 4 should rise above 2.1V normally.
<CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR> set the correct timing for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Probably more corrosion on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> pads/traces.
